column2: Looking for Love
Lost in Thought
Keeping in Touch
Focused on the Present
In the Fields Poppies Grow
No deeds shall be commemorated here…
Is this what we hope to achieve?
Wars cost lives, regardless of the weapon.
Not a Place of Honor

Riding alone on your horse, the sun blinding the way, you wander through fields of the realm you haven’t seen with your own eyes, you see something slowly emerge on the horizon. Each step from your trusty steed takes brings you closer, dismounting from your noble companion. What you see before you is a scene of battle, eroded by the centuries. Husks of machines scattered around the field, holes in the ground the size of houses, skeletons litter the ground and the cannons aimed towards the sky ready to rain fire on an enemy long gone. Resting after witnessing the remnants of ancient horrors, you see a single flower by itself next to you, a humble Poppy.
the Lion of Valour
A reward for valour perhaps?
The Lion of Victory, I like the sound of that!
You can keep it, for the right price.
For Valour

Before your bravest and oldest knight passed away, he gave to you a jewel that his family owned since time immemorial, for he had no child to give it to. You remember his acts of chivalry and valour, the tales of his great feats in battle, while waiting in an Antique Store. It is a rather strange jewelry, not made of precious stones but only of metal. Its the shape of a cross with crown, and lion atop, what has led you here however is the archaic tongue that is written on it. Exploring the store you find a strange flag with a red leaf on it and an ancient sword from beyond the Indus. What stands out the most to you however is the countless small pieces of jewelry that look similar to yours, but in different shapes and sizes. You hear two words – "of Victory” – as the historian enters the room. The two of you sit down next to his collection, he explains to you how these were once rewarded to noble warriors in the past for their actions in battle.
This has given me much to think about.
I should write more, myself.
Sentimental nonsense.
A Note from the Past

You are resting under a shady tree, and pick idly at the dirt with a stick. A few inches down from the surface, you suddenly hit a solid object. You soon uncover a rusted metal box that is clearly of antediluvian design. The box is easily opened, and you can see that time has not been kind to its contents. The box is filled with the remains of dozens of papers, and while the words are stained and faded with the centuries, you can tell these were once hand-written letters and notes. The only part of any of the letters that is still legible is at the bottom of a single page- Two sets of initials, written on the inside a simple drawing of a heart. Whoever wrote these is clearly long, long gone. But who were they? Did they die with most of the old world? What were their lives like? Did this love and affection last? How will your own life be remembered? These are a few of the thoughts that float through your mind.
Let us continue on, the dead shouldn’t be disturbed.
Bury him, its what he would have wanted.
Take all valuables, they won’t be needing it anymore.
The Fallen Craft

Making your way trough the dense woods on your recent travels, one of your companions alerts you that they’ve found something strange hidden in the foliage. Approaching the strange object you recognize its metal hull, like that of the many machines that litter the fields the commoners toil on. However it is different, its fitted with wings made of steel on its sides and back. That is when you see a fainted symbol, staring into your soul like the eyes of a veteran of wars long forgotten by countless generations. Before you can even come to an explanation of what it might mean or have meant, one of your guards calls over to you, and as you step over to him you see the remains of a man wearing a strange helmet that covers their skull. As you move away from the wreckage you say.
The City of Lights, a City of Love.
One can feel like an Emperor up here.
I wonder how tall this was?
The view isn’t even that good!
Tour Eiffel

You leave the Walls of Paris behind you in the Night, walking over the now empty fields under which the City of Lights resides, turned into the fields of harvest. Reaching the House of Invalids you see the final resting place of Napoléon, now residing under the building’s dome.  Moving past a windmill you finally arrive at your destination, the Eiffel Tower. As you make your way up on the Iron Giant, you look down upon the village below, who’s inhabitants even now cling to the remnants of antediluvian days for safety and former glory. Slowly making your way up the seemingly endless stairs in the Shadowy Night, the massive structure creaking with each step you take, but at long last, you arrive on the first floor. Exhausted you put your shoulders on the railing and stare into the night sky as the cold wind breezes your hair. You see the proudly standing Arch of Triumph, and Paris further afield filled with life and lights even in the Night.
